Was the San Francisco Bay Area mostly Caucasian back in the early 1970s?
No.
There has been a large Asian presence in the SF Bay Area for a long time--the Chinatown here was the largest population of chinese outside of China, there were lots of Japanese who'd been displaced during WWII.
for a long timea large Asian presence in the SF Bay Area been
been for a long timea large Asian presence in the SF Bay Area
a large Asian presence in the SF Bay Area for a long timebeen
The whole Western Addition and a large portion of the Haight was black.
was blackThe whole Western Addition and a large portion of the Haight
The whole Western Addition and a large portion of the Haight was black
The Mission was basically latin-american.
was basically latin-americanThe Mission
The Mission was basically latin-american
As the southeast asians and philipinos came over, they added to the cultures.
added to the culturesthey
they added to the cultures
to the culturesadded they
So, the Bay Area has been fairly mixed ethnically for a long time--caucasians may have seemed to be a large populous but that's because most tourists back then were caucasian and many of the hippies were caucasians so that's who the photographers took pictures of.
the Bay Area been fairly mixed for a long time
the Bay Area for a long timebeen fairly mixed
been fairly mixed for a long timethe Bay Area
The other ethicities weren't well represented in politics yet--or rather, they were just breaking the color barrier in the 70's due largely to the more open-minded hippy generation.

in politics The other ethicities represented

My general convince your parents to let you get a reptile advice:
1. Be responsible.

you are not just moving house - your cat is losing his territory.
house you moving
moving you house
you house moving
territory is very important to cats, and they are very nervous when they go into a new place - a new house could be full of predators, or unknown menaces - well at least he thinks so.
territory to catsis very important
is very important territory to cats
territory is very important to cats
you will need to give him only a small place to explore, so he can make it his territory, and feel safe there.
you need
need you
then, he can have a place to retreat to when he feels scared.
have he a place to retreat to when he feels scared
he a place to retreat to when he feels scaredhave
a place to retreat to when he feels scaredhe have
you will need to get his box and bowls, and whatever blanket and toys are his, and smell like home, and put him in a room.
you need
need you
the room you sleep in is best (seeing you so relaxed that you are sleeping will send the message that everything is OK), but others will work just as well.
is best the room you sleep in
the room you sleep in is best
close the door, and keep him in there for a week.
close the door
the doorclose
he will feel much safer in that one room, than in a huge unknown house.
feel than in a huge unknown housein that one roomhe
than in a huge unknown housefeel he in that one room
than in a huge unknown househe in that one roomfeel
he will explore the room, mark everything with his cheek, and try to make it feel like his territory.
explore he the room
the roomhe explore
explore the roomhe
he will reassure himself that no other animal is in there, and that no other animal will come in - he is afraid that he is in someone else's territory when he is in a new house.
reassure he himself
himself he reassure
he reassure himself
in a week's time, he will have made it his, and will be getting more bored than afraid.
it made in a week's timehe
he made it in a week's time
in a week's timehe it made

he make the whole house

remember to give him the time he needs to feel that the room is his - rush it, and he will be afraid of the whole house for a long time.

I also have back problems that transfer into my legs.
have back problems that transfer into my legsI
I back problems that transfer into my legshave
back problems that transfer into my legsI have
I have done Yoga for riders for a while, a 20 minute routine I found on YouTube (I think its called "Yoga for horse back riding" hosted by a man) It helped with noticing slight differences in my balance and weight distribution but helped not really for the way I use my legs and back.
Here is what I do now and it really helps....
Here is what I do now
what I do now Here is
When I first get on I take 1 leg and pull it back up to touch my butt with my heel and hold it there for 1 lap at a walk around a large dressage arena.
I take 1 leg
I 1 leg take
take I 1 leg
Then the same thing with the other leg.
Then 1 lap at a walk around the arena with both my legs pulled out as far as I can, so they are not touching the saddle.
Then a lap doing scissors, one leg forward as far as I can and the other back, then switch legs.
I'll also trot doing, down 2 beats, up one for a wile, then up 2 down 1 making sure the weight is going into the balls of my feet.
Itrot
trot I
If the weight is going into your heels (it throws your leg forward) put the stirrups up against the heel of your boot.
the stirrups put up against the heel of your boot
the stirrups up against the heel of your bootput
put up against the heel of your bootthe stirrups
Do a nice working trot, not a slow trot.
a nice working trot, not a slow trotDo
Do a nice working trot, not a slow trot
All this will help you use both legs evenly, keep proper contact and use your wight correctly, to keep your leg in a good position.
you help All this
All this help you
All this you help
BTW you dont want your leg locked in place, it will move WITH the horse a bit.

To answer your questions in order:
your questions answer in order
answer in orderyour questions
in orderyour questions answer
1) It is not normal for dogs to be vomiting, much less to have blood in it.
is not normal for dogs
for dogs is not normal
However, if they have been vomiting numerous times, then the blood could be due to irritation of the stomach and intestines.
He could also have Parvovirus, a GI foreign body, or any number of things.
Parvovirus, a GI foreign body, or any number of thingsHe have
have He Parvovirus, a GI foreign body, or any number of things
have Parvovirus, a GI foreign body, or any number of thingsHe

take your vet radiographs (x-rays)
2) Your vet would not prescribe them if they didn't think it would be helpful.
them Your vet prescribe
prescribe them Your vet
prescribe Your vet them
3) If he shows no interest in water, then take him back to your vet.
take him
him take
It could be due to nausea or any number of things.
He could become severly dehydrated (especially if he continues to vomit and have diarrhea).
become He
He become
From there you end up with electrolyte imbalances, which can lead to heart and kidney problems.
with electrolyte imbalances, which can lead to heart and kidney problemsyou From there end up
you end up From there with electrolyte imbalances, which can lead to heart and kidney problems
you From there with electrolyte imbalances, which can lead to heart and kidney problemsend up
And being dehydrated, vomiting, and having diarrhea just doesn't feel good.
4) Call your vet.

your vetCall

Let me try to break this down as simply as I can: diurnal (active during the day time) reptiles like the bearded dragon require 3 types of "light," UVA, UVB, and heat.
me Let
Let me
Any white light emitting light source will emit UVA, including heat bulbs, that's the easy one to provide for.
including heat bulbsUVAemit Any white light emitting light source
including heat bulbsemit UVAAny white light emitting light source
Any white light emitting light source emit UVAincluding heat bulbs
UVB on the other hand can only be reproduced by a fluorescent source.
by a fluorescent sourcereproduced on the other hand UVB
UVB on the other hand by a fluorescent sourcereproduced
reproduced on the other hand by a fluorescent sourceUVB
UVB will always be a separate bulb from the heat lamp, unless you use a MVB (mercury vapor bulb) which is the only reptile use bulb that will emit both UVB and heat from one bulb.
be a separate bulb UVB
UVB be a separate bulb
I highly recommend that you do not use coiled/compact UVB bulbs as they are known to cause severe eye damage and/or blindness in reptiles not to mention they have trouble maintaining UVB output over time.
recommend I
I recommend
The long tube UVB bulbs are best, like Zoomed's Repsitun model: http://lllreptile.com/store/catalog/reptile-supplies/uvb-fluorescent-lights-mercury-vapor-bulbs/-/zoo-med-24-repti-sun-100-fluorescent-bulb/ Remember to replace UVB bulbs according to the manufacturers recommendation after which time the bulb will no longer produce UVB even if visible light still is.
The long tube UVB bulbs like Zoomed's Repsitun model: http://lllreptile.com/store/catalog/reptile-supplies/uvb-fluorescent-lights-mercury-vapor-bulbs/-/zoo-med-24-repti-sun-100-fluorescent-bulb/ are best
are bestThe long tube UVB bulbs like Zoomed's Repsitun model: http://lllreptile.com/store/catalog/reptile-supplies/uvb-fluorescent-lights-mercury-vapor-bulbs/-/zoo-med-24-repti-sun-100-fluorescent-bulb/
like Zoomed's Repsitun model: http://lllreptile.com/store/catalog/reptile-supplies/uvb-fluorescent-lights-mercury-vapor-bulbs/-/zoo-med-24-repti-sun-100-fluorescent-bulb/ The long tube UVB bulbs are best
So, to answer your question, no, if you just have a bulb that says it produces UVA then you do not have "the sun's rays" that your bearded needs.
you the sun's rays" that your bearded needshave
have the sun's rays" that your bearded needsyou
you have the sun's rays" that your bearded needs
You need to also provide a source a UVB lighting.
You need
need You

be available for 10 - 12 hours a dayUVB and basking temp (should be about 110 F for a baby, 95 F for an adult)

Freeze dried food is not a good staple food source; you need to offer live feeder insects.
Freeze dried food food source
food sourceFreeze dried food
Bearded dragons are sight hunters, they need to see the food move to trigger a feeding response, especially when they are babies.
are sight huntersBearded dragons
Bearded dragons are sight hunters
Live food is also higher in nutritional value than freeze dried.
in nutritional value Live food than freeze driedis also higher
Live food is also higher in nutritional value than freeze dried
in nutritional value is also higher Live food than freeze dried
Crickets, silk worms, phoenix worms, and various feeder roaches, like red-lobster, turkistan, and dubia, are good example of staple insects to offer your bearded.
are good example Crickets, silk worms, phoenix worms, and various feeder roaches, like red-lobster, turkistan, and dubia

When choosing a parakeet look for a young one.

for a young onelook
(the younger the eaiser to tame) Look for clean smooth feathers, beak, and clean vent feathers (the feathers around the butt..dirty vent feathers means the bird is not healthy) Look for a dark eye with no circles (the older ones have a circle ring in their eyes).
